The game design industry used to be mostly made up of computer scientists and self-taught individuals. It did not offer many ways for people to enter the field. Many people unfairly saw video games as just a hobby for young fans, but now the industry is taken seriously. This change may surprise some, but experts in the field are not surprised. 

Getting into the video game industry is not easy. Creating video games based on new movies requires many team members and months of hard work and skill. Like many industries, it can be difficult to enter, but it is growing. Jim Donelly, a spokesperson for an online games magazine, says, “It is very hard to make progress in big companies or to influence major games. However, the industry needs game designers now more than ever. They need not only top-level directors but also lower-level designers who create systems and individual parts of the game.”

So, how can you enter this competitive field? Many companies prefer candidates with a degree in computer science, but Jim has a different opinion. He says, “The only way to get in is to make games. The tools are available. You won’t get a job if you haven’t created something, and you won’t succeed on your own if you are not making things. Game design is more than just a job; it is a way of life. Like any creative work, it must be done to be real.”

Another expert, John Field, agrees but adds that it is more complicated. “While just doing it is important, many people want to work in games, but few meet the industry’s requirements. Even fewer have the creativity, technical skills, vision, and business sense needed to succeed in this changing field.” 

Can you succeed on your own? John says, “Maybe, but it is difficult. A good postgraduate course in games can help and provide support and guidance for a year or two. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and work their way up. They are interested in all types of entertainment and have a strong interest in the arts and modern culture. They may have worked for a few years after graduation but have realized that games are their passion. They are not just fans; they are excited about the future of games and understand the growing variety in the industry. 

Connections can also help. This is often ignored, but to succeed in games, as in many fields, you need to network. The old stereotype of a young boy playing video games has changed. Now, video games attract a wider audience, including families who play on interactive consoles. Smartphones also offer many new games through apps and social media. John believes there is a lot of room for growth. “Games have become popular for larger audiences. They are also a great way to learn, and I see this area as full of new possibilities and opportunities.”

Since I was a child, I have always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, but he never forced me, and I appreciate that. I had a friend whose dad was very strict about football. He would always say, "You can't do this, you can't do that." Because of this, my friend lost interest in playing and has not played football since. I am glad that I did not have the same experience, but I know it could have been different.

When I score an amazing goal from far away, people often say it is just luck, but it is not. I have practiced taking long shots since I was young. You can only score great goals by practicing. The best players in the world have natural talent, but they also practice for many years. Sometimes, I see young players colliding with each other, but I was taught the right techniques. When I teach kids, I always tell them to enjoy learning new skills.

At school, I played many sports, from rounders and baseball to athletics and basketball. I know now that a good education is important, but back then, football was all I thought about. The teachers were doing a good job, but I didn’t realize it at the time. I want my son to have a different experience. We are already trying to read him books, even though he is too young to sit still for long. I hope that his habit of kicking the books around does not mean he will be like me in that way.

At the start of my professional football career, the manager made sacrifices so that younger players like us could join the first team, but he never made a big deal about it. He didn’t say, "This is your big chance," but we all knew we had to prove ourselves. I scored in the first game of the season, but we lost. A well-known TV presenter said, "You can’t win anything with kids," which made us realize how much we needed to improve. We had some doubts, but we believed in ourselves as a team.

I depend a lot on my close friends and family. However, having a lot of money can sometimes create problems. For example, people often ask me why I let my mother keep working. I have helped my parents financially by paying off their house loan and buying them a car last Christmas. My family is strong, and they would not like the idea of being supported by me. My mom does not earn much as a hairdresser, but she loves her job. I enjoy using my money to help those around me.

I have more money than people think, but it does not solve all my problems. After I stop playing football, I plan to take a year off or even longer to do things I have not been able to do. I want to go skiing the day after I stop playing. I cannot do that now because if I were to break a leg while skiing and could not play football again, I would not be insured.

It was because of Sam Carter that we lived at Reef Point. Sam was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. He offered to find us a cheap place to live because my father was having a hard time writing there. They did not get along at all, and my father couldn’t write anything sellable while we were in Los Angeles. Sam was worried about losing clients and money.

During the summer, the beach was empty because the sun was often covered by sea fog. Reef Point was not a popular spot for day visitors. The road to it was not very inviting, and a nicer resort called La Carmella was nearby. Most people chose to stay there instead. Only those who were broke or really loved surfing would come to Reef Point. But now, with the hot weather, the beach was full of people and activities.

My father was busy every day trying to finish a script by a deadline, and he was very stressed. While he worked, I often went to the beach with a book and my dog, Rusty. When we first moved to Reef Point, we didn’t have a dog, but Rusty started hanging around. I tried to chase him away, but he kept coming back. One morning, I felt sorry for him and gave him some water. My father threw a boot at him, but he didn’t really mean it. Rusty knew this and got closer.

I asked my father, “Who do you think he belongs to? He acts like he belongs to us.” My father replied, “You’re wrong, Jane. He thinks we belong to him.” Rusty loved the beach and liked to dig things up and bring them to me. Sometimes he found things that didn’t belong to him, like a new sneaker or a bright beach towel, and I had to return them to their owners. He also loved to swim and always wanted to join me, even though I could swim much faster than he could. Luckily, he never got discouraged.

That day, after swimming, my father had finished his script and drove to Los Angeles to deliver it. Rusty and I spent the afternoon together in and out of the sea. As the sun began to set, it got cooler, and we sat watching the surfers. They had been surfing all day and didn’t seem to get tired. They would choose a wave and balance perfectly as they rode it to the shore. One surfer caught my attention. She was so skilled that the others looked clumsy compared to her. When she decided to finish for the day, she rode in on a final wave.

“Hi,” she said, “why didn’t you join us?” 
“I don’t have a surfboard.” 
“You could get one.” 
“I don’t have any money.” 
“You’re British, right? Are you visiting?” 
“No, I live here.” 
“Is your father American?” 
“No. He came here to write a film script based on a novel he wrote.” 
“Really? Have I heard of him? What’s his name?” 
“Rufus Marsh.” 
“You mean, *Tall as the Morning*?” I nodded. 
“I read that book from start to finish.” 

She looked at me with new interest, and I realized that people were friendly but only showed real interest when I mentioned *Tall as the Morning*.

Violet Hetherington stood in a long line at the dock in Southampton, feeling confused. She remembered her friend Annie's advice: "It's best to get to the docks late. If you arrive too early, you’ll just be waiting around." Annie, who was married to a diplomat and traveled a lot, usually gave good advice. But this time, it was wrong. 

After a while, an announcement came over the loudspeakers: there was a problem with the computer system. The mood among the waiting passengers became tense. Some tried to stay patient, while others joked to lighten the mood, but most people were unhappy. They had paid a lot of money for this cruise, and it was supposed to be a special experience. The delays made Violet feel like she had made a mistake by coming on this trip.

As she searched her bag for her phone, she realized it was missing. This was more frustrating than the long wait. Without her phone, she couldn’t call the taxi company to see if she had left it in the cab. All her important numbers were saved on that phone, which was something her older son, Harry, always warned her about.

In the queue behind her, a friendly couple stood. Violet asked them, "I’m sorry, but I think I left my mobile phone behind. Could I borrow yours to make a quick call?" She called Harry and left a message asking him to ask their neighbor, Kristina, to check if her phone was at home. If it wasn’t, she would be in trouble because she had no other way to find important numbers in New York. Part of her felt relieved, but she didn’t tell Harry that. He often thought he was wiser than her, while her younger son, Daniel, was more understanding of her mistakes.

Finally, the line started to move, and Violet handed over her travel documents at the window. But when she entered the ship, her heart sank. The foyer looked like a cheap hotel, with shiny fake wood, fancy chandeliers, and carpets that reminded her of airports. She followed the signs to the elevators, which were crowded with tired passengers. As the lift moved up, it stopped at each floor, letting people out until Violet finally reached the twelfth floor. 

When she stepped out, she was relieved to find that her room had the balcony she had requested. She had worried about what to say if it didn’t. Ignoring Annie’s advice to wait for a better deal, she had decided to pay the highest price she could afford to ensure she had a nice view of the sea.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an estate auction, he had no idea he was about to discover the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was looking for pictures to include in a book about the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 images taken by Maier, a street photographer known for her amazing ability to capture interesting moments. Since then, Maloof has built a collection of Maier’s life and work. In his home attic, he keeps her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, along with many 8mm movies and audiotapes.

One morning, Maloof looked around at all this and realized he was on the edge of something special, all by chance. “When I bought this, I had no idea what it was,” he said. “I’m a third-generation flea market seller and could have easily sold it all to someone else.” For a while now, Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon have been piecing together details of Maier’s life. They reached out to local families who had hired her as a nanny and spoke with people from the shop where she developed her film.

Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. In 1951, she returned to New York and moved to Chicago in 1956 to work as a nanny. Maier was a private person who often dressed in large coats, wide-brimmed hats, and sturdy shoes. “On her day off, she would have her camera around her neck and we wouldn’t see her again until late at night,” said Maren Baylaender, whose husband employed Maier to care for his daughter. “She was private but had strong opinions about movies and politics.” 

Maier knew a lot about theater and films. Although she was not very social, she would walk the streets with her camera and talk to people, some of whom she interviewed on audiotape. She seemed to be very dedicated to her “second job” of documenting the world around her. “She was a true artist who followed her dreams,” said Rydzon. “Nothing stopped her.”

Maier’s work is a pure form of art; she did not create it for money. Her photos often focus on women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract subjects. “What is fascinating about Vivian is that she has so many interesting pictures,” said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees influences from other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her own style or borrowed ideas from others. 

Maloof often thinks about whether he will ever go through all the negatives, which he keeps in three tall, fireproof cabinets. Interestingly, he had no real interest in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her architectural photos, Maloof started taking his own pictures. “As I improved as a photographer and revisited her work, I realized that the cityscapes were not what mattered to her. It’s the people, the street scenes, and the overall composition,” he said. “There was so much more to her work than I thought, and I realized I was holding something more important than I ever imagined. Now our goal is to share her name and get Vivian Maier into the history books.”

When a novel is called ambitious, it often means it has not completely succeeded. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I interviewed her in the UK when her book was very successful, and she was at the center of a lot of attention. Despite being in her twenties, she seemed calm. She had just arrived from Germany and was flying back to New Zealand the next day. 

She shared a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She pressed her novel against the glass. The official looked at it and asked, “What’s it about?” This is not an easy question for an author. 

The Luminaries takes place in New Zealand during the 1860s, where a series of crimes have happened, and a group of 12 men has come together to solve them. The story becomes very complex. Catton said she wanted to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but she found that the past allowed for more complications and misunderstandings for her characters. The book is over 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters a fair chance to shine.

When I asked her how it feels to be so successful at a young age, she responded in a thoughtful way. “It’s nice coming from a small country because everyone feels like they share in the success. There’s a family-like feeling at home, and I received a lot of support from other people’s grandmas.” She also mentioned that it bothers her when people think her book is not serious or philosophical.

Catton explained that she wanted to write the book in the shape of a spiral, where each part is half the length of the one before it. This means the story speeds up as it goes along. I asked if it matters whether readers notice these patterns. She said she wanted to create a book with interesting structures that readers could discover if they wanted to.

Despite its unique structure, The Luminaries is still an exciting murder mystery with a captivating plot. Surprisingly, Catton said she did not plan the story in advance. “I would write myself into a corner and then see how creative I could be to get out of that situation.” One of her goals was to make the book enjoyable for readers.

We also talked about her love for television dramas, which often have cliff-hangers, different viewpoints, and dialogue. I asked if she would be interested in writing for TV. “That could be pretty cool,” she replied. She spoke with excitement and laughter about her work and New Zealand. 

“I notice that when I come to Britain, my imagination changes just by being in a different place. I understand why writers leave New Zealand for more populated areas to be around more people.” For now, New Zealand will remain her home, and I hope it continues to inspire her for many more novels.

As a boy, Jonny Kinkead spent his time either making things in his dad’s garage or playing the guitar. For the last forty years, he has been building steel-string acoustic guitars by hand. He says, “I’m still amazed by the guitar. How can two pieces of wood create such beautiful sounds? Different types of wood make different sounds, and it still surprises me.”

Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven. At sixteen, he wanted to learn the bass guitar. Instead of getting a job to save money for one, he decided to make it himself. He studied how different shapes and types of wood affect sound and how to put them together. The bass guitar was the first instrument he built from scratch, but he and his brothers had been making model boats and planes for a long time. Their father taught them how to use tools like saws and chisels. Jonny had also been customizing and repairing instruments for his friends.

Although Jonny’s bass guitar turned out well, he didn’t think about a career in guitar-making at that time. He was also interested in painting and sculpture. After finishing school, he chose to study architecture at university because it involved design. However, halfway through the course, he dropped out. He felt too different for that path. But he left with a clearer idea of what he wanted to do. He realized that building guitars is a form of sculpture that creates sound, and it seemed more practical than pure art because people actually use the things he makes.

Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows part-time to earn extra money. His first guitars were sold for just the cost of materials, but as he became known as one of the best guitar-makers, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, he says he is “still scratching a living.” He can only make about ten guitars a year, which limits his income.

In the early years, Jonny focused on getting known. He attended music festivals most weekends, letting musicians try his guitars and encouraging them to talk about him. He also had to learn how to price his instruments, which was difficult for him.

Jonny believes it is easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. When he started, many people thought only American-made acoustic guitars were good. UK-made guitars were not seen as valuable, even though there have always been good instrument-making courses in the UK. Now, however, the quality of handmade guitars from the UK is recognized.

Jonny thinks new instrument-makers should take courses to learn valuable techniques. However, he also believes that learning through trial and error is important. He advises looking at other instruments to see what works and what doesn’t. “If you make the back too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. If you learn from someone else, you might only learn one way, but if you teach yourself, like I did, you learn everything.”

Any discussion about English conversation usually starts with the weather. Following this tradition, I will mention the famous saying by the 18th-century writer Dr. Johnson: "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This saying is still true today, just as it was over two hundred years ago. However, many people who write about this topic either stop here or try to explain why the English are so interested in the weather, but they often fail. They make a mistake by thinking that when English people talk about the weather, they are genuinely interested in it. 

For example, the American writer Bill Bryson points out that English weather is not very interesting. He says that in England, we do not have exciting weather events like tornadoes or big storms, which are common in other places. This makes it hard to understand why the English are so focused on the weather. On the other hand, the English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman disagrees with Bryson. He believes that English weather is interesting because it is unpredictable. He says that while we may not have tropical storms, living near the ocean means we can never be completely sure about the weather.

From my research, I believe that both Bryson and Paxman are missing the main point. Our conversations about the weather are not really about the weather itself. Instead, talking about the weather is a way for English people to connect with each other. For example, phrases like "Nice day, isn’t it?" or "Ooh, isn’t it cold?" are not really questions about the weather; they are simple greetings or ways to start a conversation. 

This type of weather talk is similar to how monkeys and apes groom each other to bond socially. There are specific situations where weather talk is used. Some people think that the English talk about the weather all the time, but that is not true. There are three main situations for weather talk: as a greeting, as a way to start a conversation, or as a topic to fill awkward silences. 

Because of this, it may seem like English people talk about the weather a lot. A conversation might start with a weather greeting, then move to more weather talk to break the ice, and return to weather talk when there is a pause. This is why people from other countries, and even some English writers, think that the English are obsessed with the weather.

Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain, trying to explain to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds how amazing it was that the Romans built something 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were interested in this trip, choosing it over more popular tours to Spain, Greece, or France. However, they wanted to know why the wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not good enough. 

When she could not find a suitable historical novel to help her students understand life at the Wall during Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After teaching for 31 years, Alice started her new career as an author in 2001. She felt that moving from teaching to writing was a big change. “Teaching is like acting; it’s a performance every day and very demanding. Writing is exciting and a bit scary, but it’s not as tiring. My former colleagues envy me because I still connect with children through my stories,” she said.

Alice wants her novels to fill a gap in children’s fiction today. “Many young adult books focus on negative experiences. They are well written, but often dark, or they are total fantasy, like Harry Potter. My books are different.” Alice always tried to teach English and History together, using lessons about ancient Greece alongside the novel Tale of Troy. She loves seeing the moment when a child goes from being bored to interested and then from not understanding to understanding. “I enjoy having bored children because it challenges me to make them engaged,” she explained.

Alice was inspired to write her first novel because she saw a need for it, but she also felt the change coming as her two sons were leaving home. Her head teacher suggested she take a creative writing course, which surprised her. “I had been teaching for 25 years, and she thought it would be good for me. But I didn’t want to spend my summer on a course I didn’t think I needed.” Before she could join the course, she had to send in her best piece of writing, which she only learned about a few days before the deadline. “I sat down and quickly created a story about a Roman couple and their baby. Three hours and 30 pages later, I sent it in and was accepted right away.”

During the course, other students reviewed her work and encouraged her to publish it. With only 8,000 report cards as proof of her writing skills, she asked her head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. Alice’s husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and his help was very important in editing her book. Alice said, “My mother-in-law thinks we are rival authors, but I believe we work well together. He helps with the structure of my writing, while I tend to add more scenes. That’s the difference between a fiction writer and an editor.”

To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to take part in a special race. This race would have Jonny in a car and Alistair on a mountain bike, racing against each other in the beautiful but cold Yorkshire Dales in northern England. 

“I’m looking forward to it,” Jonny said at the start line. “I’ve never done anything like this before; it’s exciting! The views are beautiful, and it’s very cold, so I’ll be warm in the car.” Alistair, dressed in warm cycling clothes, was also excited. “Honestly,” he said, “I’ve seen Jonny drive before, so I’m not sure he will make it. I might stop for a cup of tea halfway!”

The race began at Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and would finish at Fleet Moss, Yorkshire’s highest road, which is about 350 meters up. This would be easy for the car, but Alistair had to climb a steep hill right from the start. After a quick handshake, they were off. Alistair quickly rode away on his bike, while Jonny got into his car and started driving. The big question was: who would reach the finish line first?

Jonny’s confidence quickly faded. Just 15 seconds into his drive, he faced a giant tractor blocking the road. “Welcome to Yorkshire,” he complained to the cameraman in his car. After getting past the tractor, Jonny continued driving, while Alistair struggled with the steep hill. He had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, passing walls and fences. Sheep watched curiously as he kept moving forward.

Finally, Alistair reached the top of the hill. With the sun shining and open land ahead, he started to pick up speed. Meanwhile, Jonny faced another challenge. The narrow roads in the villages of Yorkshire were not made for fast driving. He had to slow down to get around a tight corner and then drove through a stream on the road. Once he was clear of the last village, he raced straight towards the finish line.

Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped down the final stretch to Fleet Moss, Alistair was racing across his last field and back onto the road. He pushed hard, and then suddenly had to brake as he reached the finish line. Looking up, he asked the crowd, “Is he here?” When they said no, he raised his arms in celebration, shouting, “Yes!”

A few minutes later, Jonny arrived in his car and stepped out. “Well done,” he said, feeling disappointed. “I’m gutted.”

The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass, toss it up to serve, and hit it, hearing only the echo of your own shots. The well-kept grass, the rich history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all create a calm atmosphere that helps you focus. The quiet of Centre Court is good for my game. What I find most challenging in a tennis match is to block out everything except the game and the point I am playing. When a point ends, the silence is broken by loud applause, cheers, and people shouting my name. I hear them, but it feels distant. I don’t think about the fifteen thousand people watching me closely or the millions watching around the world as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life.

I had always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, who has been my coach since I was young, taught me that this is the most important tournament. By the time I was 14, I was sharing my dream with friends that I would play there one day and win. Before 2008, I had played and lost to Federer twice – in the final the year before and the year before that. The loss in 2006 was not too hard. I was just happy to have made it that far after turning twenty. Federer won easily, but my defeat in 2007 was much harder. I knew I could have played better; it was not my skills that failed me, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room after that loss. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and lose it.

Toni, who is usually very tough on me, surprised me by saying there was no reason to cry and that there would be more chances at Wimbledon. I told him he didn’t understand; I felt this might be my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete's career is, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment is important, but some moments are more important than others, and I had let a big one slip away in 2007. There was nothing Toni could do to make me feel better. But he turned out to be right. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I was confident I had learned from my defeat; this time, my mindset would be strong. 

The night before the final, at dinner with family, friends, and my team, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t tell them not to, but they understood that I was already focused on the game in my mind. From that moment until the match started, that focus was mine alone.

In early April 1957, a young and idealistic Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa. In her first letter home, she wrote, “I am living in the Africa I have always longed for.” Jane would spend most of her life in Africa, working as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. 

In 1963, the National Geographic Society in Britain helped make Jane Goodall famous by publishing articles and making television documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew even more through her own writing, including popular children’s books and the bestselling book "In the Shadow of Man," published in 1971. This book has been translated into 47 languages and is still available today. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, second only to Marie Curie, a Nobel Prize winner. However, her fame sometimes overshadows her real achievements.

Many articles and interviews tell her life story, but they often focus on her as a young girl seeking adventure or as a privileged woman who wanted to live with wild animals. These images do not fully represent her important work. Jane Goodall should be recognized as a leading zoologist and a pioneer in her field because of her extensive research and the influence of her students in biological sciences. 

Her main achievement is that she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before her research, people thought wild chimpanzees were very dangerous, and many misunderstandings existed about them. For example, no one knew that chimpanzees ate meat or used tools, and we did not realize that they share similar emotions with humans or have complex social systems. Jane discovered that chimpanzee communities in Africa have their own cultural traditions.

Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe," published in 1986, is considered the most important work in chimpanzee research. Her long-term study of wild chimpanzees in Gombe State, Nigeria, is seen as one of the great scientific achievements of the Western world. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves as humans.

Even as a child, there were signs of the scientist she would become. One clear example happened in the autumn of 1939 when she was just five years old. One day, Jane disappeared, and her family and the police searched for her. After a long search, she returned, covered in straw. When her mother asked where she had been, Jane explained that she wanted to know how hens lay eggs. To find out, she had hidden in a henhouse for five hours until a hen laid an egg. This moment can be seen as the start of her journey as a biologist.

During our first hour-long conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using the voices of a cheeky 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, a funny elderly Scottish woman, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are familiar to people who watch children’s TV shows and cartoons, as well as those who have seen health and safety training videos. “I just did a voiceover about back injuries,” she says, “so I had to learn how to say many medical terms quickly.” 

Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. “Many actors, even famous ones, think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,” she says. “But there is more to it. You need to bring the script to life for an audience that can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many well-known people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions because of their fame, but often they don’t get the roles because they are used to acting with their whole bodies.”

After school, Shirley joined a drama course, hoping for a traditional acting career. During the course, she occasionally sang jingles for TV ads. “One day,” she says, “the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the voice of a rabbit in a cartoon. It seemed silly – I didn’t study drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and surprisingly got a major role.” Shirley discovered she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. “Things just happened for me,” she says. “In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character, her brother, and her mother.”

Adult female actors often provide the voices for young boys and girls because their voices are lighter than those of male actors. Hiring child performers involves complicated procedures and many forms, which production companies prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create different sounds and collects new voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the best part of her job, which also includes educational videos and vacuum cleaner ads. “Those are tough because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my experience helps,” she says. “I’ve learned that the trick is to smile while you talk – it makes your voice sound bright and cheerful. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; interacting with other actors makes a big difference.”

The competition for voiceover work is strong, and having a good showreel – a recording that shows what the artist can do – is very important. “It’s worth investing in a strong showreel,” Shirley says. “There are agencies that help voiceover artists create them.” She believes she has reached the top of her profession through hard work as much as talent. “Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.”

For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley suggests attending “specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.” She also thinks a love for human sound is essential, describing herself as obsessed with voices and becoming the characters she plays. “If I’ve been in the studio doing a specific American voice, for example, it can take over me, and I’ll be speaking like that for hours or even days afterwards,” she says. “My children have grown up hearing their mom talk in completely different voices.”

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This is understandable because cartooning is a job many children dream about, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually give up these childhood dreams and think about more practical jobs, like being a tax lawyer or making car parts. The idea that you can make a living by drawing simple pictures, like those in high school notebooks, seems silly. Yet, some people do it.

Not everyone becomes a cartoonist in the same way, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I had a typical childhood for a cartoonist. I loved comic strips, contributed to school publications, and was known as "the kid who draws." I studied graphic design in college and, after graduating, I showed my illustrations to different companies. I was lucky to find someone at a newspaper who needed political cartoons about local issues. I created some ideas, and they bought them. In a few months, I was making enough money to support myself.

You don’t need much to become a cartoonist. You don’t need a university degree, a lot of money, or even to be a great artist. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. However, if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as there are teachers. The barriers to becoming a cartoonist are low, but it is still a tough job. You should only try to be a cartoonist if you feel you cannot do anything else. It is much easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and gives you time for family, home repairs, and hobbies.

The more skills you have, the better chance you have of making a living with your art. I have created political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I have also worked as a writer, caricaturist, and designer. I take on all kinds of work because you can learn a lot, even from jobs you don’t really want to do. It helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about the world.

What about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs with different newspapers and magazines. But those days are fading. Today, cartooning is often an entrepreneurial activity, which means you not only have to create the work but also sell it. The more comfortable you are with selling, the more successful you will be. I have seen cartoonists with average creativity but excellent business skills do much better than those who are very talented but lack business sense.

It surprises me how often I meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried that they won’t even let others see their work! Legally, to protect your work, you just need to draw a small ‘c’ for ‘copyright,’ put a circle around it, and write your name and the date next to it. But honestly, it is more likely that no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it becomes popular online, it is not a disaster – it could actually be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and cleaning out my things. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had given me for my 16th birthday. It was a nice, black guitar made in Japan. I usually hate getting rid of things, so I wondered why I wanted to throw this guitar away. I took it to the dump and was about to leave it there when a young man approached me, looking confused. He asked, “You’re not going to throw that away, are you?” I told him I was, and I started to feel regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said yes. We went our separate ways.

In the following days and years, I felt sad about what I had done. Then, a few months ago, I opened an email that changed everything. I remembered a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it ten years later in a fish he was eating. That’s how I felt when I read an email from someone I didn’t know, a guitar dealer named Keith Rushton. He told me, “I’ve got your electric guitar.” It had been sold many times since the young man at the dump took it. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back of the guitar. He realized it was probably old, but he used my name to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was so emotional; I almost cried. I would have given him anything, but his price was very fair.

I had forgotten that my dad always put name-and-address stickers on my things, including my guitar. My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar because it was popular in the 1970s. I loved how it sounded: calming and gentle. Unlike the violin, it didn’t sound bad when a beginner played it. But I struggled to improve, so I switched to the electric guitar and played easier songs. This was also the time of punk music, when people who couldn’t play well could still be rock stars.

When I took my old guitar out of the box that Keith sent me, I suddenly remembered my birthday in 1978 when my happy parents gave it to me. Holding it again felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I sat down to play, but then I wanted to stand up and put a strap over my shoulder because electric guitars are played that way. My fingers remembered where to go. I couldn’t draw the chords, but my hands just knew what to do. My middle-aged fingers felt the familiar pain of pressing down the strings to play a chord. 

The electric guitar is not really meant for solo playing. Now that I’m learning it again, I think I should form a band. My son is learning the saxophone; maybe we can play together. Or maybe I can find other people my age who have had a similar experience. We could call ourselves “The Regainers!”

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote my book, Insomniac, about people who cannot sleep, I felt like I was one of the few warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep. Lack of sleep affects our minds, bodies, and moods. Anyone who has trouble sleeping knows how important sleep is for our mental, physical, and social health. It is good that sleep is finally getting the attention it deserves. However, I wonder about dreams. I haven’t heard much about them in these discussions. We are losing our dreams all the time. When you wake up early because of an alarm, you miss the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM (Rapid Eye Movement) sleep. This is the stage of sleep where we have the most vivid and emotional dreams. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep time in REM. So, if someone lives to be 90 years old, they will spend about six or seven years in REM sleep. When researchers prevent people from having REM sleep, they find that the next night, people have more REM sleep to make up for it. This shows that dreams are important.

When researchers discovered REM sleep in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that understanding dreams was the best way to understand our minds. However, later research did not support this idea. The focus of dream studies changed to look at the physical reasons for dreams instead of the psychological ones. Currently, there is not much agreement among dream researchers, according to Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. 

Dreams are significant. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than others. He concluded that the use of dreams increases with a person’s interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams because films are very dream-like. However, I wondered if only creative people benefit from their dreams. Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively?

Stickgold explains that dreams help us connect ideas in new and surprising ways, using knowledge from our past and present. Dreams may help us find new patterns and create combinations that break our usual ways of thinking. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when they are woken from other sleep stages. They come up with unexpected ideas that make sense in a unique way. This is what creativity is, according to Stickgold. 

I find that I write better after having intense dreams. Even a difficult dream, or one I can barely remember, seems to help me think more clearly. On those days, words and images come to me quickly, and I can hardly keep up with my typing. I don’t know how it works, but it does seem to help. 

Creativity is not just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and we all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly as we interact with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why dreaming is important.

Twenty years ago, Susie Ray left London to live in a small coastal town in south-west England. When you enter her studio, you see a beautiful view of the sea and many empty frames on the walls, along with happy photos of her two daughters. As a leading artist in the copyist art movement, Susie can easily recreate famous paintings from the early 20th century or the 16th century. However, she does not keep any of her own work. “As soon as I finish them, they go,” she says with a shrug. 

Susie is very popular. In her 30 years as a copyist artist, she has painted works by many great artists, including Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies are so accurate that art experts sometimes mistake them for the originals. While the original paintings can sell for millions of pounds, her copies sell for a few hundred to £12,000, depending on how much time she spends on them. Susie does not reveal the names of most of her clients, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors are true art lovers, but others care more about status. One famous buyer likes to show off his “Van Gogh” painting, which is actually a copy by Susie. “Many famous people pass off my copies as originals,” she says. “That’s up to them.” Some collectors keep the original painting in a bank safe and display Susie’s copy instead.

Susie is honest about her work. When she copies an old masterpiece, she tries to make it look as real as possible because she believes it is important to respect the original artist. However, she always signs her name on the back of the canvas. Selling a copy as the real thing is illegal, and even though she knows people who have done this, she has never been tempted. Those who make fakes often get into trouble. Susie admits she is not rich and has faced challenges, but her situation is better now, and she does not want to risk her reputation.

Before becoming a copyist, Susie worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden after earning her art degree. She earned very little money at that job, but it helped her develop her skills and love for plants. She had to be very precise and get everything right the first time. Although she has no regrets about that time, she is happy to have found a more financially rewarding career.

When younger artists ask Susie for advice, she tells them to learn to draw accurately. She emphasizes how much she has studied to reach her level of skill. Her training allows her to create everything from plant drawings to perfect copies of 15th-century paintings and modern abstract art, but she now focuses on French impressionists, especially Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. 

Susie believes many people think modern art is easy, but she explains that impressionists painted quickly and freely while also being very careful. This combination is harder to achieve than it seems. Given her talent, it is surprising that Susie does not create her own original art. Isn’t art about self-expression? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than her copies? She explains that her work comes from years of training, and she makes a good living from it. She has tried creating her own art, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they looked too much like photographs. 

In a way, it’s like living on simple food after enjoying meals from a top chef. Susie is a perfectionist, and that drives her work.

During her racing days, Ellen MacArthur cared most about the sea and being the fastest on it. Since she was a child, sailing had been her great passion. She felt a strong connection with the boats that took her around the world; they worked together as one. When she returned to land, everyday life felt unimportant. People would ask her about the race, and she quickly wanted to be back on the ocean, challenging nature, even in places that had almost defeated her.

After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo round-the-world race, she showed me the small, stuffy cabin of her boat, Kingfisher. This was her home, workplace, and survival space for 94 days. She explained how carefully she planned everything, even counting the exact number of kitchen paper rolls she would need. Preparation was crucial for her. She proudly displayed her unappetizing stock of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and neatly organized medical supplies. Her ability to keep the boat clean was as impressive as her sailing skills. The boat was her world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world as a boat: a small, beautiful, and fragile thing with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey on albatrosses. This experience made her reflect and see things differently. The many abandoned whaling stations served as a warning to her. She felt that humans often take what they want and move on without thinking.

When I arrived at Ellen’s office, she was finishing a heated conference call. She explained why we need to act now to save the planet. “We are not making coal, oil, or gas anymore. They are precious resources that we have only once. We need to find ways to use them wisely.” At first, her message was negative—use less—but she later realized there was a more positive way to think about it. Now, she focuses on reusing materials, like reusable industrial carpet tiles.

For the past three years, she has been visiting factories, mines, and power stations, talking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. “I will never be an expert,” she says. “But I am like a sponge, soaking up information. I couldn’t ignore the current situation. Compared to this, sailing felt selfish. This is about finding how my voice can be most helpful. It really matters.”

She also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that helps young people rethink and design a sustainable future through business and education. “I do miss the adventure of being at sea,” she admits. “It’s part of who I am. You feel connected to everything around you. You don’t have time to feel lonely. You focus on records, practical matters, and survival. My new message is not as simple as saying, ‘I want to be the fastest around the world.’ I may have been the fastest, but this work is more important than anything I’ve ever done.”

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become very famous. He hopes to inspire other kids to go outside and explore, instead of just playing on computers and video games. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves "Team Romero." Climbing Everest is just one part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, which are the highest mountains on each continent. Very few people achieve this before they turn thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of them and might finish before he becomes a teenager.

I spoke to several experienced Everest climbers, and none of them thought it was a good idea to take a 13-year-old up the highest mountain in the world. They believe that while a young climber might be strong enough physically, they might not be emotionally ready. They also doubt that a young person has enough experience to make safe decisions while climbing.

The Romero family has heard these opinions before. Paul says, "I know there is criticism, but I can’t focus on it – we have a lot to do. We think about the risks, but we believe our experience as climbers will help us. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is getting stronger and more mature."

I also wonder about Jordan’s reasons for wanting to climb. Is his father pushing him too hard? Paul insists, "This project isn’t about me wanting to be famous through my son. At first, Jordan thought it was something to do later in life, but we decided, ‘Why not now?’ We talk to him often to make sure he still wants to do it."

When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, "I just focus on reaching my goal." In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb is seen as a chance to break records. The more exciting the record, the more attention it gets. This creates a problem for Jordan. While some people think that focusing on achievements takes away from the enjoyment of climbing, if Jordan wants to inspire others, he needs to engage with the media. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something impressive, like climbing Everest.

Paul adds, "If Jordan comes home tomorrow and says he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will end this project and go to the gym."

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it’s likely they are not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they usually don’t know who he is. I just started studying music, but my classmates know as little about classical music as other teenagers do. If you don’t know who created the music, you probably don’t have any of their recordings. This is sad for fans of classical music. Last year, only 3% of concert tickets sold were for classical music events, and the average classical album sells only 300 copies. I find this hard to believe. 

So, why is interest in classical music declining? Older people often blame our love for TV and video games, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The truth is that classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who are the ones most likely to buy music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who enjoy classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I’m not a big fan of classical music. I like many styles, but my classical music collection is probably close to that 3% figure.

Why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, can be hard for us. We prefer fast talking, fast playing, and fast thinking. Experts say we can only pay attention for about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for pop songs. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while understanding classical music takes time and focus. Also, pop music often talks about issues that matter to teenagers, while classical music usually does not.

The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families would play music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. Now, you can find any music online, but classical music is rarely part of our daily lives. When was the last time you heard classical music in a store? One of my teachers says that more people are attending classical concerts now, but I doubt many of them are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but when I look at the audience, I mostly see older people. I don’t know why more middle-aged people enjoy classical concerts, but I do know that if your parents love something, you might want to avoid it.

Some people say schools are to blame for teenagers’ lack of interest in classical music, but many kids are excited to play classical music in their school orchestras. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy classical music when they perform, but it’s not their favorite music otherwise. The two activities have become separate. When we want to relax, we always choose pop music.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. “I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here,” she said with a smile. Her mother was getting out of the other side, so she didn’t hear Bonnie, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother already knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a hillside; it looked confusing at first. Then she saw signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… “Riding centre,” Bonnie said, suddenly interested. “Headmaster’s study,” her mother replied. “This way.” Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between the trees. “I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog,” Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to do that. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his study, while Bonnie waited outside the door. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. “Why should I just sit here?” she thought. “I’ll be thrown out soon anyway, so why not get it over with?” She left the building and went to the riding centre, following the sign. 

There was a nice old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but there was no one there. She approached the horses with respect. They were well cared for, and she could see that right away. Almost every stall was occupied, and she walked along, carefully looking at each horse. “I know what you’re doing here,” she said to a small pony, gently touching its nose. Then she saw the next horse and stopped. “But aren’t you the best of the lot!” she exclaimed. He was brown with a bit of white. He looked lively, which Bonnie liked. “I feel like we’ve met before,” she said, stroking his neck. “In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…” The horse’s name was Maverick. Suddenly, she wanted to ride him. “I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle. It can’t be far.” 

Bonnie was happy to find that the room with the riding equipment was unlocked. While she was busy putting a saddle on Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. When she finally sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, in charge of everything she could see. Her old school nickname had been Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. “You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick,” she said with admiration. “I really mean it because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else.” She nudged him to walk, then to trot. “If I stay here, I think you and I could be great friends,” she said. She rode around the paddock, feeling the exciting rhythm and the breeze on her cheek. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he would jump well.

I have met Cody Simpson before, and I have always been impressed by his quiet confidence. The 15-year-old Australian has already released many successful songs. So how did a relaxed surfer end up on stage in front of thousands of fans? 

“I first picked up a guitar when I was six years old and started writing songs when I was seven,” Cody says, remembering how it all began. “But I was swimming and surfing every day. Those activities were more important to me back then; I had a busy life. When I was 13 and in high school, I posted a few videos online.” 

These videos changed everything. He started by posting a video of himself and a friend singing at a school concert. Fans commented online, asking for more videos. So, Cody, who had recorded more songs at home, was happy to share them. The response was amazing. 

Cody was also a talented swimmer. He trained hard with great coaches and focused on improving his skills. But then record labels contacted him, and he had a tough choice: stay in Australia and keep swimming, or take a big risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the chance. 

“It was very hard for me – especially at such a young age – to choose a career. Can you imagine being 12 or 13 years old and trying to decide what you want to do for the rest of your life?” He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the States. “It surprised most people. I’m kind of the quiet kid,” he says, remembering their shocked faces. “I’m very modest, and I think it’s important to stay that way in this crazy world.” 

So, Cody packed his bags and moved with his family halfway around the world, giving up one dream to try to make another one come true. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and is not directly involved in his career, they support him from behind the scenes. Cody believes it’s important to have a close group of good people around you to stay grounded. 

Of course, everyone has days of doubt. “Sometimes when I’m alone, I think, ‘How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?’ My little brother is eight years old, and he travels the world, doing school on the road; he doesn’t have a normal life,” Cody admits. “I worry about how this affects him, but my family always reassures me that they support me in everything I do.” 

Success in any career comes from being willing to say ‘yes’ to your big break, even when it’s a little scary. “It all happened so fast and unexpectedly,” Cody says. “Now, I’m going to countries I never thought I would visit and playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it’s something many people dream of. But I know it won’t last forever.”

I jumped out of bed, pulled back a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked down at the river. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I squinted and looked upstream at the sandbags that were there to stop the buildings from flooding as the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting the sandbags last week. I had worked long hours with most of the adults in town to help. But my grandfather didn’t seem to notice. 

With one hand on the curtain, I looked at the stretch of dark water created by the release pipe from the wood factory in Milltown. There were fragile ice shelves on both sides, and solid ice further down the river. As I took off my pajamas and put on my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the other side of the river. I didn’t know him. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for my lucky chain – a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. It means more to me than his fame, and only he, my mom, and I know about it. I also have his diary from that trip, which I keep under my pillow and read before I sleep. I touched the chain again and went to the kitchen.

“Good morning, Rex,” my mom said with a smile as I took a banana from the counter. “You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training. Be careful.” 

“Thanks, Mom.” I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into my tall grandfather as he came out of his room. 

“Can’t you watch where you’re going?” he shouted. “Where are you going?” 

“Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.” It was obvious from my wetsuit, but he always acted like he didn’t see me in my kayak every morning. I tried to ignore his anger, but it was getting harder. 

“What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,” he said. His words hit me hard, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He walked away and slammed the bathroom door. My mom came over with a sympathetic smile. 

“Don’t mind him. He’s…” 

“...not himself right now,” I finished for her. I didn’t say that he had always been like this. But like my mom, I tried to be understanding. When I was younger, he was my hero. He showed me photos of himself in National Geographic magazine, and those old photos still hang on his wall, along with his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own trophies to look at, and maybe one day, my own picture in National Geographic. Still, a part of me wants to stay loyal to him, even though he is grumpy.

My mom smiled. “At least he’s coming out of his room more. Have a good training session, Rex. I admire your determination to keep going, even in this cold weather!” 

I smiled back as I peeled my banana. “It’ll be warmer in South America if I find sponsors for my expedition.” She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I finished my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried to the boathouse.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her into the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unframed painting. It was clearly one of Grandpa’s works, but it looked different from his usual style and was obviously not finished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I’ve never seen it before. I didn’t know he was working on anything."

Jess looked closely at the painting. It showed a river that took up most of the picture. It was not a river she recognized, and it might not even be real; it looked like a fantasy river. The painting was strange and beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was very small, with just a hint of green that was easy to miss. The viewer's eyes were drawn to the pale water, leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people in the painting, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant scene. Still, Jess felt a connection to it, thinking about autumn coming after a long summer.

Mum spoke again. "It has a name." There was something in her voice that showed her excitement, even though she tried to sound casual. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his paintings. He just painted them and let others figure them out. Mum turned the painting over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud: "River Boy." The words felt important to her, but she didn’t know why.

There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. It’s strange, isn’t it? For him to be so specific. But maybe he will add the boy later since he hasn’t finished it yet. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn’t help it. It’s such an unusual painting, especially with a name. You can guess what he said." Jess didn’t need to guess. She knew Grandpa would have said, "It’s not the artist's job to explain a painting. Each picture has its own life and language, like a poem. We either understand it or we don’t. Painting is hard work, and I can’t waste time explaining it to everyone."

Mum laughed and interrupted her. "Something like that. Anyway, I was hoping you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him." "Inspire?" Jess asked. "Yes, a muse is someone who inspires an artist." Jess understood the word. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but he usually meant that the muse was not helping him that day or that he needed to be nice to the muse because he had a tough part to work on. He never suggested that the muse was her. She always thought he meant a kind of goddess, not a real person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as strong-willed as Grandpa. "He doesn’t need me to inspire him," she said. "He’s been painting all his life."

When I woke up this morning, I didn’t plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I’m not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad’s Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have gone into the carpet and made a big hole. That could have happened, but I’m not saying it did. I just want to say that I didn’t mean to damage the carpet. I didn’t wake up thinking, “Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.” It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things often do. Later, I wondered why I thought that, but by then it was too late. This happens to me quite often. I’m a bit unlucky in that way.

What I was really doing was trying to find a way to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved from her house to a flat. It’s very cute! It’s small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and it has tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it, like shepherdesses and old-fashioned ladies selling balloons. Now, I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I loved her corner cabinet, so I was very excited when she gave it to me!

The problem is, it is a corner cabinet, which means it has to fit in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it’s the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is for Mum and Dad, the back one is for my sister Angela, the little one over the garage is for my brother Tom, and my room is the size of a broom cupboard. Mum says that when Angela goes to university, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. Then, when Tom goes to university, I can choose any room. But since Angela is only fifteen, I think I will be stuck in my broom cupboard for a long time. 

I don’t really mind; I like my little bedroom. It’s cozy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one corner, and my wardrobe is in the other. I tried to fit Gran’s cabinet into the space between the roof and the floor, but it was just a little too tall. I thought, if I can’t cut anything off Gran’s cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. Dad calls this “lateral thinking.” I thought he would be pleased with me because he always tells us to “think outside the box.” And that’s exactly what I was doing!

The novel "The Borrowers" tells the story of a family of tiny people who live secretly in the walls and floors of a house. They "borrow" things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the book, I knew it would be difficult to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong opinions about how it should be done. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I wanted to avoid criticism from fans.

The author wanted the series to show the story from the Borrowers' point of view, not from the humans'. This made filming more complicated. The most important thing was to get the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so when we filmed them walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to be ten times further away than usual. To film their surroundings, the crew had to crawl on the ground and shoot from no higher than 15 centimeters. They went through many pairs of jeans!

We only raised the cameras for aerial shots. One big challenge was to create the right shadows when combining the tiny Borrowers with the normal-sized background. We developed a special technique for this. After the series aired, famous director George Lucas called to ask how we did it.

The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with large objects to make the actors look small. It was very surreal. I remember asking them to carry giant scissors, and they really got into it. The coins we used were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift, which made the crew laugh a lot. 

In the story, there is a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, the actors had to go down a tunnel with hoses, and they found it so scary that they didn’t need to act. 

Getting the costumes right was very important to me, and it was a challenge for other directors in different versions. I had the costumes made from heavy canvas so they would look like doll clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to move; she couldn’t sit down during breaks and had to be sewn into her dress every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal fabric would have looked too smooth. Unfortunately, it was very hot during filming, and I don’t think they appreciated my attention to detail!

Most of the action away from the Borrowers' home was filmed with the actors in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren’t really there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how they should look, and by the end, I had done 2,000 drawings. They weren’t perfect, but they worked. 

We didn’t have enough budget for special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly. Once, I filmed a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera! But in the end, everything came together, and I think the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, expecting to see journalists, but there are none. I wonder how long it will take for the chaos to start. It always does. The fake smiles, the people who want to be my friends, and the ones who ask for free tickets to my dad’s concerts. “Everything will be fine,” I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone in this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted. I wanted to escape my old life of traveling and tutors. While the rest of the band is here for recording, we are staying for good. I insisted on coming to this school because I want to meet real kids. I want to meet kids with normal parents, like a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns. That would be so cool and normal.

I walk into the school’s main office. “Hi, I need my schedule, please,” I say to the school secretary. “Name?” she asks, looking unfriendly. “Desert McGraw.” “Desirée?” she asks, leaning closer. “Desert,” I repeat. The secretary looks confused. “Oh,” she says and types “McGraw” on her keyboard. That’s good because not many people recognize my last name since my dad uses a stage name. “What grade?” she asks. “Eleventh.” “One second, it’s printing,” she replies. Then she tears the paper and hands it to me. My first class is English Literature. Great! I like English. But I will be late. English is in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map last night so I wouldn’t look silly trying to find my classes.

When I reach the door, I hear the teacher calling names. “Aurelio Gonzalez.” “Here.” I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles and looks at my normal outfit—jeans and a T-shirt. “Nice shoes,” she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with flowers on them. Oh no, I shouldn’t have worn these. “Thanks,” I say. The teacher pauses and says, “Desert... McGraw?” hesitantly. “Here.” The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After explaining the books we will read this year, she lets us socialize! All teachers should understand how important this is.

“So why did you move here?” my new friend asks. I have a few options. Should I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or should I tell the real reason my dad gave? “We need a change, Desert,” he said, “and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.” Essence? I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they choose South Beach Sounds, a recording studio so close to the sand? “My dad had to relocate,” I tell her. Yes, lies are easier. “What does he do?” she asks. Whatever. Everyone will find out eventually. But at least I can pretend to be normal for a while. “He’s an artist,” I say, playing with my backpack zipper. “Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.” And she doesn’t seem to care. Great!

Not only is the average American teenage girl expected to be the president of the Student Council, but she also needs to have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in all these areas. This is what it means to be a teenager in America today. Boys and girls cannot just go to school and be average; that is no longer enough. Being mediocre is not acceptable, and not having strong ambitions is seen as laziness. 

Kristen Loose, a teenager, says, “People, often adults, forget how much pressure we have these days. We have a lot of homework, tests, after-school activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to have a social life.” Even though these stresses are normal for teenagers today, negative stereotypes still exist, often spread by the media. These stereotypes include being lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers may fit these descriptions, many believe it is unfair to label the entire generation this way. 

Kristen Loose thinks that many people assume teenagers spend most of their time watching TV or using their phones. She admits to having her cellphone nearby most of the time, but she uses it for important things, not just for fun. For teenagers, their phones are tools that help them manage their lives. Today, students are expected to have quick access to information and to be reachable at all times, which can make it seem like they are addicted to their phones. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their homework anywhere. Instead of just listening to music on the way to school, they might be listening to language lessons. This means that schoolwork and other activities now require attention all day and night, adding to the stress for already busy teens.

Many teenagers start their days around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often finish their activities after midnight. Their days are filled with school, after-school activities, family responsibilities, and homework. Then, they have to wake up and do it all again the next day, often getting less than the recommended nine hours of sleep. A survey by the US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of American teenagers get the recommended amount of sleep. Additionally, 28 percent of teens said they fall asleep in school about once a week because they are too tired.

Teenager Lindamarie Olsen believes that after all her activities, she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. Olsen rarely spends her free time on social media or watching TV. Instead, she puts a lot of her energy into volunteering. She says, “People think teenagers only care about themselves and their own interests.” However, Olsen enjoys volunteering and looks forward to making a positive impact in her school and community.

In 20 years, the stereotype of teenagers may change, but they will continue to challenge these ideas and make a difference in the world. There will always be new generations of students who are making their mark before they even finish school.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a mountain town in the US, surrounded by wilderness east of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In recent years, this group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This project combines science and adventure, which is likely why teenagers want to join. I visited them one weekend in late spring as they prepared to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or piece of metal from space enters the Earth's atmosphere and creates a bright trail of light.

As it got dark, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the bottom of the balloon.
