Just over a year ago, I left my job to work with huskies in the Arctic Circle in northern Finland. At 26, I felt restless and dreamed of cold, empty landscapes, maybe because I was tired of the busy life in London. I found a small company run by Anna McCormack and her husband, Pasi Ikonen, in Finnish Lapland. They offered me a job as a husky dog handler for the busy winter season. From December to February, they take many tourists on sled rides pulled by huskies across the ice and snow, for trips that can last from one hour to five days. They started with six dogs, but now they have more than 100. Recently, they took over a second place called the 'wilderness farm,' which they described as a beautiful but basic location with unreliable electricity and no running water. They told me I could join the team for three months if I understood what I was getting into. "The hours are long, the conditions are tough, and the work is very physical," they said. I started packing right away.

November 6, London: On my flight, I stared at a page with over 100 pictures of huskies. I was supposed to memorize their names before I arrived, but I felt distracted and nervous. I put the page down and looked out the window instead. It is said that spring moves north at about 26 km per day, bringing flowers and leaves. However, I felt like winter was moving south, and the rivers were freezing.

November 7, Helsinki and Hetta: The bus ride north was just what I hoped for. We drove through endless dark forests with thin trees covered in snow, stopping sometimes to let reindeer pass. I arrived at the farm after dark, and as soon as I walked in, I was given a pair of boots and sent out into the cold. "Do you want to be thrown in at the deep end?" Anna asked. I followed the sound of barking, which grew louder as I reached the dog sheds. Three people were running back and forth, pulling the huskies out and getting them ready for sleds. The dogs were very excited, pulling against their ropes to get going. I could barely introduce myself because everyone was too busy. I stood to the side and petted one of the quieter dogs. Someone told me to "Get in!" and I almost fell into the nearest sled. A command was shouted, and suddenly we were off into the dark, with only a headlamp for light.

November 15, Hetta: It didn’t take long to become part of the husky guides, but first, I had to answer some tough questions about what I could do. "Are you useful?" Anna asked. I was confused. I didn’t know if I was. After more questions, I realized I wasn’t very useful: I had never driven a snowmobile, hadn’t done woodwork since school, and had never chopped anything with an axe. "Do you have a driving license?" someone asked finally. I nodded, feeling relieved. 

I learned the basics of dog-sledding quickly: lean into the corners, use both feet on the brake to stop, and never let go of the handlebar. But many other things were complicated. Simple tasks like feeding and watering the dogs became hard in freezing temperatures. A bowl of water would freeze quickly, so we had to make a 'soup' of meat in hot water for the dogs. By the end of my first week, I was overwhelmed with instructions, and my muscles hurt from pulling heavy sleds and being pulled around by excited huskies. But I felt proud. "I can chop with an axe, hammer a nail, and use a circular saw," I emailed my friends. "In the snow."

On that day, as Radcliffe ran past the finish line, reporters gathered to understand her amazing performance. They noted that her time was fast enough to qualify her for the men's marathon at the world championships in Paris. Curious journalists asked her about a special natural treatment called emu oil, which Olympic gold medalist Cathy Freeman had suggested to help Radcliffe heal from an injury caused by an accident when she ran into a bike while training. Radcliffe said that the achievement didn’t fully hit her at the time. Looking back, she realizes it was a big deal, but she felt it was just what she was meant to do that day.

She and her support team had decided not to set any limits on their goals. Their motto was "no limits." During the race, Gary Lough, Radcliffe's husband and coach, was in a car with her support team, listening to the radio coverage. Gerard Hartmann, her physiotherapist, was also with him. After 16 kilometers, Radcliffe's agent wondered if she could keep up her fast pace, worried it might make her drop out of the race. Hartmann was angry at this concern, but he understood that anyone who didn’t know how fit she was might think it was risky to start so quickly.

With 800 meters left, Radcliffe started to think about her time. She realized she could finish in under 2 hours and 16 minutes if she ran the last part in less than three minutes. She had already run 41 kilometers very quickly but still managed to sprint the final distance in 2 minutes and 25 seconds. At the finish, she thought, "I can run faster than that." She remembered the race director, Dave Bedford, saying he never thought anyone would come close to that time for a long time. Radcliffe thought, "I will come back and do it next year," and she really believed she could.

Unfortunately, that did not happen. After the race, everyone wanted to know how an athlete with such an unusual running style had beaten the skilled East African runners. Hartmann had worked with Radcliffe for weeks, giving her daily training sessions to help her manage the 250-300 kilometers she ran each week. He said, "I've worked with 63 Olympic medalists, and no one could handle the level of pain she could. She would tire me out because I had to work so deep into her muscles that I would have to ice my thumbs afterward because I was in so much pain."

Hartmann described traveling 13 hours from his home in Ireland to Radcliffe's training base in France, only to be greeted by her husband saying, "Gerard, you're 15 minutes late, Paula's waiting." There was no "Hello, do you want a cup of tea?" She was ready for a two-hour training session as soon as he arrived. "Paula would push you to your limits. That's what made her so good." During this time, Hartmann dedicated so much of his time to Radcliffe that his other athletes became upset.

Can Radcliffe explain why no one has come close to her record? "Not really. I trained very hard, but there are more talented people out there. I thought Mary Keitany (a two-time London marathon winner) would do it. Maybe it's because people are racing against each other instead of racing against themselves." What does she mean? "That mental attitude of never slowing down, even when you are winning, probably helped me because I never thought, 'I can relax now.' It was always about pushing as hard as I could."

Radcliffe did not know it at the time, but that marathon was the peak of her career. She would never run that fast again. However, she inspired many women to take up long-distance running.

When my first cooking show, In Search of Perfection, was released, I was unsure how viewers and critics would react. There was a lot of talk about a food ‘revolution’ happening in Britain, and I believed we had created a series that truly contributed to this change. However, I worried whether people would enjoy a cooking show that included not just techniques but also history, memories, and science. I watched the first episode feeling both happy and anxious. I didn’t need to worry. The show became very successful, leading to many exciting projects, including a book about my experiences at my restaurant.

In each project, I felt like I was on a journey, whether into the past, into my thoughts, or into cooking techniques. I wrote several books in a series called ‘Perfection’, each one linked to its own TV show. In these books, the journey was often physical, involving passports, suitcases, and travel plans. The latest book, In Search of Total Perfection, takes you around the world to meet amazing artisans, like a man who creates golden pasta that tastes better than any other. These artisans have spent many years trying to achieve their own ideas of perfection.

Perfection is very personal. Even choosing which dishes to include in the series was difficult, and I knew I would disappoint some people by not including their favorites. I could imagine people asking, “Where’s steak and kidney pie and bread and butter pudding?” However, after a long meeting with the TV production team, we finally created a list that would satisfy everyone. This experience confirmed my belief that everyone has their own idea of perfection, shaped by their emotions, memories, and experiences.

Despite the book’s title, I knew I wouldn’t claim that the recipes were the best or final versions. I believed that by using my cooking skills and scientific knowledge, and by talking to food producers, artisans, chefs, and their customers, I could identify what made these dishes special. The dictionary defines ‘perfection’ as being perfect, but it also means improving through constant experimentation. This means trying out ideas and changing them until you create something unique.

The TV series allowed me to explore many foods, people, and places I had never seen in restaurants before. I was excited to discover memories and nostalgia in food because I started my career in the same way. Finding the best ingredients took me around the world. I had many adventures, like visiting a canning factory that was processing the wrong type of tomato and going to a dairy farm that did not meet our standards for perfection, which made us stop filming there! While perfecting each recipe, I ended up hand-milking a cow, using dry ice to make ice cream, cooking chicken in a hospital scanning machine, and almost burning my house down trying to get the oven hot enough for a real Neapolitan-style pizza.

We were still a long way from Marrakech when the van made a loud noise, swerved off the road into a field, and stopped. John got out and opened the hood. He looked at the engine for a long time with his hands in his pockets, looking serious. “Actually, I have no idea what I’m doing,” he finally said, and he and Mum started to laugh. Bea was worried, “We can’t stay here forever,” she said. The field went on for miles, with just grass and many flowers, like poppies and daisies. “No, we can’t stay here forever,” I agreed, because it was best to support Bea. We got back into the van and waited for Mum and John to stop laughing. We watched John get smaller as he walked away to find someone who could help with the van. Mum lay down on the grass. “Tell us a story,” she said. Bea lay down next to her. “Go on, tell us a story.” So I told them about how the day before we left London, I heard two birds talking. I shared everything they talked about: breadcrumbs, other birds, the weather, and an argument over a worm. “That’s silly, no one understands bird language,” Bea said. My eyes felt wet. “I do.” But I didn’t sound very sure. “Liar.” I felt embarrassed. How could I be lying if I remembered everything? The more I thought about it, the less sure I became. “Mum…?” But she had fallen asleep in the sun. John came back with three Moroccan boys who helped us push the van down the road to the hotel. Bea didn’t want to get out. The boys didn’t mind at all. They waved and smiled at her through the back windows. We followed John into a café that was not far from where our van was parked. “It’s a hotel,” John whispered. “I think it might be a bit expensive.” “We’ll just have some tea,” Mum said, and we sat in the shade. The tea they brought was made from mint leaves and was very sweet. Mum looked into the pot. “It’s like syrup in there,” she said. We stayed at the café all day while John looked sadly at the engine. “I guess it’s a miracle it got us this far,” he said as it started to get dark. Mum took out blankets and made a bed for us in the hotel garden. It felt nice to sleep on the ground. “I’ll have to get us towed into Marrakech,” John said from the other side of Mum. Half an hour later, we were in a truck watching our van being pulled behind with John driving. At first, Bea didn’t want to move, so John picked her up and put her in the truck. Now she sat in the front with the driver. I kept wondering how we would get home now that our van had to be towed everywhere. I thought it might be easier to take a boat straight to London. Then I must have fallen asleep.

Lucy was at a welcome party in a hotel ballroom, talking to two other pianists who were also at the Prague Classical Music Festival. One was a guy from Tokyo, and the other was a girl from a European city named Liesel or Louisa. They were both about ten years older than Lucy and spoke good English. They discussed the music they were playing and their recent travels. 

“I think I'm doing Tanglewood this summer,” Lucy said, trying to sound impressive. However, she didn’t really want to go to the Tanglewood festival. She often felt overwhelmed by the concerts and competitions that took her around the world, making her miss so much school that she was no longer officially enrolled. Instead, she worked with tutors from the University of San Francisco. 

Lucy hadn’t even wanted to come to the Prague Festival, which only accepted fifteen pianists her age from around the world. She was one of the lucky few chosen from thousands of applicants. At the celebration, her dad gave her a white-gold necklace with an L pendant to congratulate her, and her little brother Gus dreamed about being at the same festival one day. Her teacher, Grace Chang, took her out for a special dinner to plan her music pieces. The truth was, Lucy hadn’t applied herself; her mother had filled out the form and sent in a CD. “I didn’t want you to be disappointed if you didn’t get in,” her mom had said. Lucy thought her mom just didn’t want to let her say no. Back then, she believed that making waves was the worst thing to do, so she didn’t think about trying to back out.

The guy from Tokyo leaned in, seeming surprised. “Tanglewood?” he asked. “Yeah,” Lucy replied. “How old are you?” he asked. “Fifteen,” she said. He looked at Liesel/Louisa, who said, “Wow.” Lucy hadn’t meant to brag; it was hard to know when she was just sharing her experiences or showing off. 

“It’s just part of this new youth-spotlight thing they’re trying,” she explained. Just then, Liesel/Louisa looked across the room and said she had to go talk to someone. The guy from Tokyo stayed and asked, “Have you ever been to Japan?” He had long, messy hair, like many musicians, to show he was a cool music nerd. “Once, when I was about eight,” Lucy replied. He started to say something when Lucy's grandfather appeared beside her. 

“Lucy, let me introduce you to someone,” he said, pulling her away. “And don’t get too friendly with the competition.” “They’re not the competition,” Lucy replied. “Everyone is the competition,” her grandfather insisted. He took her around the room, making her talk to important people. Lucy smiled and nodded, understanding only part of what was said.

Later, in the elevator to their suite, her grandfather told her, “You did well in there, Lucy. I’m proud of you. This is an important festival, and people are talking about you. They all know who you are.” Lucy liked that. Being recognized felt good, even if some people were jealous or thought she was too young for the attention. Being a concert pianist didn’t earn her respect from the kids at her old school. Even her best friend, Reyna, didn’t know or care that she could play a difficult Rachmaninov piece. But in places like this, Lucy felt she mattered.

Text: "‘It’s not good for you to spend so much time online. You need to get out into the real world,’ said Dad. It’s hard to argue with him, so I decided to see what experts say about this topic – and it’s quite interesting. Research shows that most teenagers who use social media have many real-life friends, a strong sense of identity, and are learning important technical skills for the digital world. Simon Miles, an e-safety expert, says ‘social networking is now a big part of growing up. Teenagers don’t just use media like adults do – they live in it. This isn’t necessarily good or bad – it depends on how you use it.’ 

How does our social networking compare to what our parents did when they were young? Jim Matthews, a social media analyst, says it’s like the modern version of hanging out at a youth club, where parents used to share jokes and gossip. He believes it helps teenagers build their identity away from their parents and learn to handle teenage issues with their friends. 

Psychologist Professor Keith Davidson says: ‘Adolescence is a time when you ask, who am I? Social networking can help you find your identity: you can share your favorite music or sports, discover what you like, and see that others have different opinions. Research shows that active social networkers are not as self-centered as those who don’t use social media.’ He adds that social media can help shy people: ‘Talking online can be easier than in person, and it allows you to practice social skills in a less stressful way.’ 

Professor Andrew Phillips is studying how young people use social networking sites. He believes they can help quiet people with special interests connect with others who share those interests. ‘If you’re one of only a few people in your school who likes a certain type of music, you might feel alone. But if you find a social networking group of people like you, you can feel more connected and popular in a different way,’ he says. 

Pauline White, a digital education expert, shared something interesting: ‘It’s young people who find new interests online, join groups of like-minded individuals, and create their own content who are really using social networks well.’ She thinks social networking is becoming a creative tool: teenagers are making videos, podcasts, and blogs about what interests them. Photo-sharing sites are helping photographers connect, learn skills, share images, and grow their passion. ‘This all helps with job opportunities and will be useful in the workplace,’ she says. ‘Every business uses social media to sell and build their brand – and you need to know how it works to attract customers. For example, if you create a product and have 1000 friends on different social networks, they could all be potential customers. If you connect all those networks, you have your customer base.’ 

Teenagers who use social networking creatively will benefit when they become adults and enter the job market, agrees Matthews. ‘One great thing about many sites is the chance to work with others to create content and share it. Collaboration is an important skill in the 21st century and is key to being employable in a digital world.’"

When most people think of a relaxing family vacation, they might not imagine a long trip across nine western states in the US and a Canadian province. However, my parents were not looking for a quiet getaway when they planned our summer vacation this year. My dad seemed determined to create what he called the ultimate family bonding trip, which my twin brother and I found terrifying. “Not enough people do this anymore,” my parents said repeatedly before our vacation, while we exchanged worried looks.

In mid-June, we packed our car with suitcases, coolers, and a mix of clothes for any weather. I was excited but knew I would miss my privacy for the next two weeks. With barely enough space left in the car, we began “The Family Great American Road Trip.” Leaving our big home for smaller places for the next five thousand miles made me wonder what we had gotten ourselves into.

We drove west through the Oklahoma panhandle. Even though we were still close to home, we had our share of adventures. We stopped for the night in Oklahoma, under a sky full of stars, after almost being blown off the road by a dust storm. We quickly learned that cattle have the right-of-way on the road!

The next day, we woke up early and continued our journey. The desert changed to mountains, and the days started to blend together, but each adventure was still unique. We left our footprints in the Great Sand Dunes and then went to Pagosa Springs, Colorado, where we noticed a strong smell of sulfur. As we climbed to our next stop, we realized that the roads marked for Jeeps were best for Jeep drivers.

Every place we visited showed a mix of old and new. Dealing with construction traffic became normal. We laughed when we saw the big “CLOSED” signs at the Four Corners Monument. On our way to Yellowstone National Park, we saw many wind farms and watched the sunset over bear habitats near the roads. We experienced “bear jams,” where traffic would stop to let bears cross, and we had a close encounter with one bear and an anxious park ranger, which created unforgettable memories.

As we continued our trip, life back home felt far away. Even the hotel we stayed in, which was old and had no internet or cell phone service, couldn’t dampen our excitement. In exchange for these inconveniences, I enjoyed the most beautiful views I had ever seen. After watching a rainstorm from our hotel in Canada, my family and I headed back south. My parents were right: you don’t need to travel to a faraway place to find something amazing.

Returning home was a mix of happiness and sadness, but at least I hadn’t fought with my brother during our one hundred hours on the road! We had three thousand photos from our journey to look through and remember. I knew that the best memories would be the unexpected and spontaneous moments we shared.

Rose Frost was sixteen years old and was going to live with her grandmother, Daisy. Rose's family was separating for two years. Her father, Jeff, had a job overseas, and her mother, Dahlia, would join him. Rose and her older sister, Amy, would stay in England. Amy needed to finish her last year of school, so it was better for her to stay. She was happy because she got the best room at her college, which had its own kitchen and study area. She also had free access to the Internet and phone. Jeff and Dahlia would keep an eye on Amy, whether she liked it or not. 

So, Rose was moving to her grandmother’s house. She only had vague memories of her grandmother from past holidays and had never met her grandfather. When Daisy offered Rose a place to stay, her parents were not excited about it, but Daisy was happy to have Rose with her. Rose didn’t fully understand why her parents didn’t get along with her grandma, but there had been a disagreement in the past. Because of this, Rose had spent her summers away from Daisy, even though she had happy memories of her. 

Dahlia told Rose that living with Daisy would be interesting. Daisy was very social and loved to bring people together. Rose could expect dinner invitations, coffee mornings, and shopping trips soon. This thought made her smile. Daisy was not a typical old lady; she seemed to go to more social events than anyone else. 

Before the move, Dahlia and Rose had a serious talk. Rose was sensible and mature for her age. She knew about healthy eating, staying fit, and getting enough sleep. But she wanted one thing: her independence. Living with Daisy would meet her needs, but Rose wanted to play music loudly, invite friends over, and go out without asking for permission every time. She didn’t want to be reminded about homework or staying out late, and she didn’t want to be taken around by her grandmother. Daisy understood. 

Dahlia gave Rose a new touch-screen mobile phone with a video camera for emergencies only. Rose was very happy about this. They all agreed that it would be about trust. Daisy would trust Rose to make good decisions, and Rose would trust Daisy not to be too strict. If either of them crossed a line, they would talk about it again. 

Rose was not a wild child. Her few school friends were similar, so her school reports were always good, and her exam results were excellent. This helped her a lot. In five weeks, Rose would start at a new school, meet new friends, and begin her life again. This would be her fourth senior school in five years, so she felt experienced. At least she knew this would be the last time, as she would be starting her final two years of school. For Rose, it was a new moment in her life, a new piece in the puzzle of her experiences.

Charlotte Grainger shares that her primary school teacher was the first person to think she might write a novel. She says, “I believed that writing a book would be a great achievement because it seemed very challenging. I didn’t know what other teenagers were doing, like competing in the Olympics. When I turned 13, I thought, ‘I should try this now.’” The novel she started at that age is now about to be published. She recently told her former teacher about it, and the teacher was surprised. The teacher had thought Charlotte would write a book when she was 30 or 40, but Charlotte never considered waiting that long. 

It is a winter afternoon in the offices of Charlotte’s publishers. Even though I knew I was going to interview a 15-year-old girl about her book, I was surprised to see a teenager sitting there. The book is a significant achievement: it has a strong and exciting story. Nothing about it, except for the age of its main character, suggests it was written by a teenager. A public relations representative is with us in case Charlotte needs help, but she doesn’t. She is confident, smart, and steady, which keeps her from being overly confident.

Charlotte understands that she is still young. When I ask her about the complex moral questions in her book, she says, “I was trying to ask big questions, not answer them. I don’t have many life lessons to share with my readers.” She laughs and adds, “I don’t think my age limits my understanding of the world, but I also don’t think I’m very wise. I just wanted to explore the idea of taking responsibility.”

Charlotte has a theory about how teenagers are often misrepresented in books aimed at them. She believes there are three types of teenage characters in novels: the outsider who becomes accepted, the naïve teenager who knows little about the world, and the awkward teenager who struggles socially. She finds it frustrating to read about these types. “What if you’re basically fine? There aren’t many stories about teenagers who aren’t struggling in some way. Some writers give the impression that teenagers can’t know who they are because they lack experience, and that can hurt their self-confidence.”

Charlotte has always loved reading famous fantasy authors, but their work almost discouraged her from writing. “My favorite fantasy books explore deep topics about psychology and life. I wondered if I needed to write like that to create a good book and if I was capable of it.” However, she appreciates a book called How Not to Write a Novel, which taught her that if readers can guess what will happen next, the suspense is lost.

Some might say that having parents who are journalists helped her get her novel published. In fact, her father knew someone in publishing who read her book first. Charlotte recognizes her good luck because it is hard for anyone to get a first novel read, no matter their age. “Every aspiring writer needs support and a bit of luck, but after that, you are on your own. Ultimately, writers succeed or fail based on their talent, so I don’t take anything for granted,” Charlotte concludes.

"‘Remember, speed is your friend, not your enemy,’ said Gareth, our instructor, as we looked down the ski slope. ‘Now, who wants to go first?’ The group looked nervous. Then a guy named David, who had some experience with freestyle ski-jumping, stepped forward and skied down the slope towards the jump. He went up the ramp quickly and flew into the air, but something seemed wrong. We held our breath. He landed hard, lost both skis, and flipped into the snow. ‘Remember,’ Gareth said kindly, ‘speed can be unpredictable.’ 

I started to think that maybe freestyle skiing wasn’t for me. On previous ski trips, I had enjoyed practicing turns in the snow, but I wasn’t like the teenagers who did tricks on ramps and half pipes. I thought it looked fun, but I was afraid that if I tried to join them, I would embarrass myself. Then my parents decided we would have a winter holiday at a freestyle skiing training center in the US. The center had a big indoor area with trampolines and ski jumps covered in artificial snow. Students practiced their tricks and landed in foam pits, which was not a realistic way to prepare for the real slopes.

After practicing indoors, students went outside to try their moves for real. ‘Progression is inevitable!’ the center’s slogan said. ‘Before places like this trained people, inexperienced ski jumpers would just throw themselves down the slopes and hope for the best,’ Gareth explained. ‘But remember – if you land on the knuckle, you’ll be in trouble.’ The ‘knuckle’ is the flat area behind the jump before the slope gets steep again. If you land in the right zone, you keep moving forward, which is safer. If you land on the flat, you stop suddenly, which can hurt. So, speed is important.

At first, it was hard to convince my body to ignore my fears and go straight towards the jump. My legs seemed to want to go backward as I got close, and I often landed on the knuckle. I didn’t fall, but by midday, I felt exhausted. ‘You need to control the jump, not let it control you,’ Gareth said. 

On the second day, we started on the trampolines. I thought I would hate being indoors while looking at the snowy mountains, but bouncing on the trampolines was fun. Some exercises copied the moves we would make while ski-jumping, and others helped us learn ‘aerial awareness’ – understanding what our bodies were doing while spinning in the air. Gareth gave us tips. My ‘aerial awareness’ needed improvement because every time I tried, I only remembered the moment before take-off and then found myself in the foam cubes next to the trampoline.

We returned to the mountain to try again. There were more mistakes, but eventually, I landed properly. Gareth was as happy as I was, and for a moment, I felt proud of achieving my goal. But that feeling didn’t last long. On my last run of the day, I made myself keep my speed up as I approached the jump, flew into the air, and landed correctly. Then I saw both of my skis sliding down the slope, no longer attached to my feet."

Imagine you are on a rollercoaster at an amusement park. Your hands are sweaty from fear, and you grip the harness tightly. Suddenly, the ride stops, and you take a deep breath as the carriage slowly climbs up. There is a pause, then a sudden drop that makes your stomach feel like it’s in the air. You rush forward, turn sharply to the left, and go upside down. Everything around you is a blur, and you scream in fear. But you chose to be here, just like millions of others who pay to enter theme parks.

What surprises me is that amusement parks, with their thrilling rides, are a huge business. To create the excitement and escape from reality that visitors want, there are large teams of creative engineers and designers working behind the scenes. The idea of being a "rollercoaster designer" might sound like a child's dream job, but it is actually very challenging. Designers must find the right mix of fun and fear while keeping riders safe. They also need to come up with new ideas to keep people coming back.

While many people think rollercoasters are getting more intense, most of the techniques used today were actually invented by a US designer named John Miller in the early 1900s. During his time, there were fewer safety rules, and some rides were very extreme, which made many passengers uncomfortable. Now, designers have to follow the track designs made by special ride manufacturers.

I talked to three experts about rollercoasters. Professor Brendan Walker, a "thrill engineer," explained that the skill lies in putting all the parts together. Dr. John Roberts, a member of the Royal Academy of Engineering, added that it’s important to quickly switch between feelings of excitement and safety so that riders feel thrilled but not scared. 

To create an amazing ride, the teams must develop a strong story, like a space adventure or a jungle chase, that fits with new features like the tallest drops or the most twists. However, Professor Walker noted that, like in many creative fields, experience and instinct are crucial. Jeff Hornick, a senior director of theme park development, agreed that it helps to be passionate about thrills to understand what riders want and to test the rides before they open.

I asked the experts if rollercoaster designers would use new technology like virtual reality. Walker said we shouldn’t expect too much from it. He explained that while virtual reality can enhance the experience, the real excitement comes from the physical ride itself, which will continue to be the main attraction for many years.

At 25, Miranda Ellington has already done a lot as a choreographer, creating performances for many theatres and dance companies. She also dances occasionally. I wonder why she manages to do both activities in her busy life. She explains, “Dancing again reminds me of what it’s like to be in the studio, following the orders of strict choreographers, and how stressful that can be. Choreographers can forget what it feels like to rehearse all day.”

As a choreographer, she teaches and enjoys working with young students. “A new dancer is often open to trying new ideas. Sometimes, working with students is easier than with professionals because they are willing to take risks. They want to succeed but don’t yet fully understand their strengths and weaknesses. This lack of understanding helps them accept even tough criticism. However, they might still question what I say, and I appreciate their honest feedback.”

When Miranda starts with a new group, she focuses on the dance steps, and the music guides her. “There might be music I don’t like, but I still try to create the best dance routine for it. If dancers don’t respond well to a certain piece of music, it can be frustrating, but I need to find solutions. I can’t just choose a new piece of music. I wish I could be more experimental and switch to different pieces, as it would help improve the mood during tough rehearsals. Unfortunately, I often work on large productions where the music is already decided by the composer.”

Miranda believes in making connections with new people. “It’s important to meet new people, but I have to remember that each theatre and school has different methods and styles. I need to adapt my way of working each time I go somewhere new, instead of doing the same thing everywhere. This helps me avoid becoming too set in my ways.”

We discuss a recent documentary about professional ballet dancers and choreographers. “There have been glamorous documentaries in the past that were misleading,” Miranda says. “This one tries to show the real life inside a dance company. There’s a scene where a young dancer receives many corrections, and I smiled because I recognized that feeling. She knows she’s not getting it right but can’t make her body do what’s needed. It’s hard to watch, but it’s real. People often underestimate the hard work and dedication needed in ballet.”

I ask Miranda what makes a great dance production. “It’s when everything the company has worked on – the music, costumes, lighting, and dancers – comes together. Perfection might be too much to expect, but aiming high is appreciated by audiences and can help cover up some mistakes. I’ve been part of productions where the dance steps were great, but something about the costumes or props was distracting, and that’s disappointing.”

Miranda has done many different types of work, so I ask how she sees herself: is she a modern dance choreographer or a ballet specialist? “People want to label you, and I don’t understand that. There’s also a trend to focus on becoming an expert in a narrow area. I don’t follow that, but maybe one day I will be known for one thing. For now, I just want to explore more.”

A friend once asked me why I travel when I can see everything on television. I agreed that there are amazing things on TV, but why stay at home when there is so much to experience outside? This conversation inspired my crazy four-day trip and a film that encourages people to turn off their TVs. 

A friend was getting rid of his old sofa, which became the main part of my film. I added three wheels and some cables to it and connected them to old seatbelts over my shoulders. I put my luggage on the sofa and slept on it each night, even one night on the beach. Some friends joined me, helping to pull the sofa and encouraging me to keep going. 

I have done many walking trips in recent years, but this was something completely different. It was the longest distance I have ever walked, and I walked on main roads. This allowed me to stop at roadside cafés and relax on the sofa with a cappuccino instead of sitting on a rock with my sandwiches blowing away in the wind. 

I often had to tell people, “No, I’m not doing this for charity, and I’m not training for a marathon.” When someone at work asks about my weekend, I prefer to explain how I dragged a sofa 100 miles across southern England rather than talk about the latest TV show. You can watch the film on my website.

When I read about guided swimming trips in the sea around some small Greek islands, I felt excited. I had never tried organized group trips before. My brother, who I had traveled with before, was busy, so I thought a group holiday would be good for me. The man at the Greek port looked surprised when I asked for a single ferry ticket because the islands are popular with families. I explained that I wouldn’t be alone for long; I would be joining ten others to swim around the small islands. Although he still looked confused, he smiled and let me on the boat.

Our group had exchanged emails before we left, but there was little time to talk before our first group swim. Our guides told us that a support boat would follow us the whole time and made sure we knew how to communicate with it. We did a short swim to divide us into speed groups, and then it was time for our first real swim of 1.5 km. I was nervous. I had trained in my local pool and done some river swimming, but I had never swum long distances in the open sea. Soon, the waves got bigger, and I found myself at the back of the slow group, which was not where I wanted to be. I watched the faster swimmers move ahead like dolphins. However, I wanted to finish this first distance, and I was very happy when I finally did it on my own.

The next days followed a routine: jumping in, finding a comfortable speed, and stopping to enjoy the beautiful views. As the swims became longer, my speed and enjoyment also increased. I felt like I didn’t need the support boat anymore. I can’t wait to come back again next year.

Being a flight attendant is not easy, but it has many rewards. Since I started this job, I have traveled to many places, from the US to Australia. I work with amazing people, have plenty of time off, and my life is always interesting. This makes it a great job for someone young like me!

When I was a child, I went to a boarding school far from my family. I often flew alone when school started and ended. Sometimes I felt lonely, so I asked the flight attendants if I could help serve meals to passengers, and some of them let me. This experience stayed in my mind when I wanted to leave my banking job and find a new path.

At the interview for the flight attendant position, there were many young people, and many of us were hired. Most of us had good qualifications and were changing careers. Before the interview, I practiced what to say. I didn’t just say I loved to travel, like everyone else. Instead, I talked about my skills and past work experience, and I got the job!

I would recommend this job to anyone because there are many reasons to enjoy it, but the free flights are not the best part. Most airline staff work very hard, and there is a saying: “No one is finished until everyone is finished.” It feels like a big family. Even if we don’t see each other all the time, we are still close.

When I am not working, I don’t have to take my work home. If I do have difficult passengers, which is rare, I know the flight will end soon, and I probably won’t see them again!

At the summer camp where I work, I really enjoy watching the children succeed at things they never thought they could do. Most of the children already know how to swim and play table tennis before they arrive, but rock climbing is a new experience for many of them. Some children feel very nervous, but after some encouragement, they agree to try, and in the end, they all reach the top. This makes them feel great.

At the beginning of the week, some children miss home. It is not the younger ones who feel this way the most; it is usually the ten- to thirteen-year-olds. We do not allow them to use their mobile phones all the time. First, we tell them they can call home after lunch. When they ask again, usually after dinner, we say it is too late to call now and suggest they do it tomorrow. Most children feel better in a couple of days, and by the end of their week, they all come to us and thank us because they have had a great time.

It is not only the children who feel lonely. Sometimes, parents call us all the time to ask how their child is doing, which is not necessary. Often, their son or daughter is busy playing games or doing other activities, so we have to tell the parents to call back later.

We also see a certain type of child who comes to camp, usually dressed in expensive new clothes. These children often argue when we ask them to change into something more suitable, but soon they understand why it is important.

Text: 'Rock the Planet is a musical show where the actors also need to be good musicians. It opened in London last year after being in the USA for five years, where it won the title of ‘Best Musical’ four times! However, putting on the show with an all-British cast was not easy. The UK has more rules about how many performances young actors can do each week compared to the USA, where they can perform more often. Because of this, they needed twice as many actors in the UK. Fortunately, the director found many talented actors from the UK, and they have just won their first ‘Best Musical’ award. 

The theatre in London is bigger than the one in the USA, and it has been full every night, with many people wanting to hear the songs that became popular in America. I met Jamie, an 11-year-old actor in the show. He said, ‘It’s amazing that I get paid to play, especially with a beautiful and expensive Gibson guitar.’ He shared how busy the young actors are. ‘We have regular school lessons at the theatre every day. The teacher is great, but I miss my old school friends.’ 

I asked Jamie what his classmates thought of the show. He replied, ‘My whole class came! The theatre offers special ticket deals for schools. They loved it, and that made me feel really confident. My parents come when they can, but it’s expensive for them.’ When I mentioned that I also play guitar, Jamie found a spare one and invited me to play with him and the other young actors. We played a song called Days, which I didn’t know. Jamie helped me learn it, and I felt proud when I finally got it right. I was impressed by Jamie’s talent and wished I had similar skills. I was just trying to keep up and was glad the show’s director wasn’t there to hear my mistakes!

Although the young actors were already musicians, some playing several instruments, none had played in a band before. Luckily, they found it quite easy. Jamie said the hardest part was looking natural when they first performed together. They were so focused that they forgot to smile! The show will be in London for another year, and it is definitely worth seeing.'
